Problem:
Consider a complex function \\( z(t) = e^{i\omega t} \\) where \\( \omega \\) is a real constant, representing a time-dependent state in a system. We analyze the impact of the integral transformation defined by \\( T[z](t) = \int_0^t e^{i\omega s}z(s) \, ds \\) over time t.

If the transformation \\( T[z](t) \\) is applied to the state \\( z(t) \\) at t = 0 and then allowed to evolve following the original definition of \\( z(t) \\) without further interventions, will \\( z(T) \\) at t = T be the same as if the state evolved naturally from t = 0 to t = T?
Explanation: The integral transformation \\( T[z](t) \\) modifies the trajectory of the system by integrating the past states, thus affecting the subsequent evolution of \\( z(t) \\). This results in a different state at time T from just evolving \\( z(t) \\) where \\( \omega \\) dictates the rate of change and phase.
